ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a strong basis in multivariable calculus, learned to draw and visualize 3d space, and improved my revision skills for exams
You get a very good grasp of computational multi variable calculus and its applications.
This course was great for my calculus and math knowledge in general and greatly developed my skills.
A general overview of multivariable calculus.
Learned multi variable calculus and logic behind calculations. Great course.

This course offers a well-structured overview of major topics in multivariable calculus, drawing connections between Greens, Stokes and the Divergence Theorem, among others. I developed the ability to visualize the underlying logic behind important concepts.
multi variable calc
Expands on previous calculus knowledge and applies it to multi dimensions, generally develops quantitive reasoning skills.

I gained an extensive knowledge of
multivariable calculus, but also improved my
determination and problem solving skills
through completing the problem sets, as well
as stress management and effective studying
through preparing for midterms.
In this course, I learned about concepts in three dimensions such as Stoke's Theorem and the Divergence Theorem.
Calc 3
A thorough understanding of Multivariable Calculus topics and how to apply them, mathematically and conceptually.

This course taught me how to think critically. Working in a new dimension (3-D) was a wholly new concept for me, and it was difficult to grasp at first but I learned how to work around it. I also learned how to apply concepts taught in class to problem solving.
I learned the fundamentals of calculus to help me in my future classes

Knowledge of how to think in multi variable systems and fundamental mechanics of how to analyze these systems. I also developed useful knowledge of how to think in new ways in three dimensional space and how to solve complex problems using learned knowledge.

I learned how to better connect different topics in Multivariable calculus to specific applications. I think Professor Hall did a great job of distinguishing between similar ideas while also showing how they relate to one another.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This cause is extremely well planned, I always know what the expectations for class assignments are, and the combination of videos and lectures make it easy to clear up any issues with the content.

Strengths: well organized, interesting content, fair exams, I had a great professor

Weaknesses: problem sets are sometimes unnecessarily tedious (long messy integrals, ugly expansions,etc.), professors vary greatly
This. Purse is literally perfect

I thought the way the course was taught was reasonable, but I believe that their grading methods are a bit flawed (when it comes to showing work). I believe that if a student gets the correct answer to a question without showing parts of their work, they should not be penalized. However, if they get the question wrong without showing their work, then the grader has the right to take off as many points as they seem fit. I believe this to be a fair tradeoff.
taught very well by John hall. Extremely structured. Honestly have no improvements for the class.

The material is structured in a way that gradually builds upon earlier knowledge, so if you keep up with the material being taught you should not feel completely lost when new topics are introduced. The course covers a good amount of material over a short period, so you need to review key concepts in your own time.
super interesting (pro), super fast pace (con)

Smaller sized sections helped a lot with learning because it felt more comfortable to ask questions and easier to follow along. Sometimes it felt as if teaching varied a little between sections so that when working with students from other sections, it would be hard to know how they were taught a subject or if they were on the same lesson as you, which could make working together on psets more difficult.

I believe the online videos and textbook
readings are excellent aids in the course.
Sometimes classes were very similar to videos,
with quite a bit of overlap. Though problem
sets were definitely beneficial, I felt sometimes
they had too many problems focused on the
exact same material and demanded too much
time to complete thoroughly. Midterms were an appropriate level of difficulty, though the
second midterm makeup (which I took) seemed significantly more difficult than the original second midterm.

I personally found this course to be extremely poorly paced. While the content in the beginning was relatively light and easy to understand, as the course progressed, the content became increasingly difficult with fewer time to digest it. I also wish we had spent more time in understanding how different topics might relate to one another. 

Additionally, I found that if one did poorly on one examination, this might negatively impact their whole grade throughout the semester - given that this course is often an introductory math sequence course for first years, I would have hoped for some more leeway while adjusting to Yale.

Wish homeworks and in class content were closer to each other in terms of time (we did homework on stuff we learned two or three weeks before). Also the homework questions were just too time consuming without teaching or reinforcing important concepts

I appreciated the access to pre-class videos and the practice problems in class. I felt that this structure, with psets, gave me enough opportunity to understand and apply the topics. I was well-prepared for exams.

I think this course was done very well, and that the student interaction and lectures by Professor Hall were really good. The only significant thing that I would change would be having no psets due the week of a midterm.

Class time was used to reinforce material learned before class with the expectation that pre-class work had been completed. I feel that it should be the other way around for a class like multivariable calculus. Though it makes sense to have students have some background before heading into the classroom (so the pre-class work is useful in that way), it should not be the entire foundation of the course.
The content material was well spread out, but I wished the lectures could be recorded.

The course is well structured and communicates information well. It can sometimes be easy to fall behind with all the reading before every class but that feels like a personal issue that the teaching team is not responsible for. Overall, the course is very strong in giving a thorough understanding of the ideas it teaches and allowing students to be curious. I cant point out any significant weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this is a great intro multi class, and is easy to follow
Yes. For most, its not a choice, but either way I think the tools you learn are very interesting and useful.
Yes, its the best math class Ive ever taken
Yes, the professor is great and the challenges never seem impossible.
Yes, if the student already has a clear knowledge of single-variable calculus.
Yes!!! John hall is extremely organized and clear in his explanations. Very grateful he was my teacher.
Yes. If you want or need to learn multivariable calculus, this course will do a great job acquainting you with the material.
if you need it
Generally a good course for upper level math, though can be difficult at times, so I would only recommend to a student who has good reason to be taking upper level math/ is very good at higher math.

Yes, if that student is interested in
mathematics. I personally am probably not interested in pursuing math further at Yale, and felt the workload of the course added significant stress to my semester without the joy that courses in my preferred topics provide. For a student looking to fulfill a math credit, I would recommend the class as long as they are willing to put in the effort to understand the material. Given the choice now, I would probably choose to take the course again, though the time commitment and stress would give me pause.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they a) have already taken multivariable calculus outside of Yale or 2) are considering majoring in math, physics, or engineering. As someone who was learning the content of the course for the first time, I found myself at a great disadvantage as a lot of my peers already had a preliminary understand of the content. Additionally, as someone considering the pre-med track, I found that this course did not align with my interests.
If its required
Yes, it's useful for many degrees, but I wouldn't necessarily take it if it doesn't apply to your major.

I would only recommend this course if you need it or are very interested in it because it is fairly difficult and a lot of work. However, I thought it was done very well, and was formatted in a way that was both interesting and fairly easy to understand if you put the work into it.

I would not recommend this course to another student that does not intend to pursue a major in mathematics. This is not the same as high school math and it requires a lot of analytical and critical thinking skills that go above and beyond what is taught in the classroom. (in other words the class doesn't teach you how to think in order to solve a problem, which is what you need to complete the problem sets).
Yes, this course helps alot with stem majors

If the student is interested in learning the material in the course, I would absolutely recommend they learn it through this class. It is well structured and a good environment to learn about these ideas.

Yes, if you plan on pursuing anything math-related, this would be a great course. It's well-organized (at least with Professor Hall), and I came out with a clear understanding of each of the topics and how they may relate to other topics.
